p: The legal concept of viral sovereignty is a phenomenon of the new millennium, and it is one we are stuck with. The international regime created by the CBD and Nagoya Protocol defaults to bilateral ABS negotiations on a case-by-case basis. 130 This default mode of ABS is extremely time consuming and not appropriate in global health emergencies where time costs lives. The PIP Framework uses an alternative mode: a multilateral agreement that might be considered a specialised ABS instrument under the Nagoya Protocol. But the PIP Framework has major flaws as an ABS instrument 131 and, as we have seen with H7N9 influenza in China, can be easily circumvented by any party not wishing to accept its standardised terms and conditions.
